abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Population Project (Family
            Planning and Safe Motherhood) for Indonesia achieved a
            satisfactory overall outcome. Overall performance by both
            the Borrower and the Bank were rated satisfactory, and the
            Borrower's implementation performance was rated highly
            satisfactory. The project's investment appears, on
            balance, to be sustainable. Key components and activities
            relating to service and information provision and quality
            improvements have been absorbed into ongoing programs of the
            Family Planning Coordinating Board (BKKBN). As for the
            component under the Ministry of Health (MOH), follow up
            activities and projects have been designed to address
            factors bearing on the professional and economic viability
            of village midwives. There were four substantive key lessons
            learned. First, addressing the needs of specific population
            groups as well as increasing the effectiveness of existing
            programs requires plans that better reflect local needs and
            conditions. Second, improving the quality of services is
            essential for addressing the unfinished work in family
            planning and maternal health services. Project resources
            were reprogrammed to address this issue and follow up
            initiatives have been launched. Third, it became apparent
            that the completion of the village midwives (BDD) training
            and deployment program will not be adequate to address
            maternal health needs. The Government of Indonesia must
            address this policy issue in the near future. Fourth, the
            project-financed pilots successfully demonstrated the need
            for intensifying efforts to enhance coordination of demand-
            and supply-side interventions. Finally, lessons related to
            project implementation revolved around: investment projects
            as tools for addressing policy reforms; annual planning and
            flexibility in project design; performance-based contracts
            for research; and ownership and leadership by implementing agencies.
